citations.narrative:
Two primary enclosures for birds are still in need of repair.
**Adult macaws are group-housed in an outdoor wire enclosure that still has multiple sharp points and excessive rust. The
sharp points and rust are frequently found throughout the wire panels around the enclosure.
** An outdoor wire enclosure housing chickens and guinea fowl still has multiple sharp points. The sharp points are found
around areas that the birds frequent such as the water and food receptacles.
Enclosures with sharp points may cause injury to the birds within. The facility must ensure that all primary enclosures be
constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp edges that could injure the birds. The primary enclosures must
also be kept in good repair.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The physical environment for multiple bird species including amazon parrots and macaws had either no or very limited
enrichment through materials or activities. There was no additional cage complexity provided, nor objects to manipulate or
any use of foraging or task-oriented feeding methods. The macaws were observed chewing on the wire panels of the
enclosure. These behavioral signs may indicate that enriching the physical environment is necessary to provide the birds
with means to express non-injurious species typical activities. The physical environment in primary enclosures must be
enriched by materials or activities at an appropriate frequency to promote needs the psychological welfare of the birds.
Correct by January 1, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.153(a)(1)(i)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures. 
Two primary enclosures for birds are still in need of repair. 
 
**Adult macaws are group-housed in an outdoor wire enclosure that still has multiple sharp points and excessive rust. The 
sharp points and rust are frequently found throughout the wire panels around the enclosure. 
 
** An outdoor wire enclosure housing chickens and guinea fowl still has multiple sharp points. The sharp points are found 
around areas that the birds frequent such as the water and food receptacles. 
 
Enclosures with sharp points may cause injury to the birds within. The facility must ensure that all primary enclosures be 
constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp edges that could injure the birds. The primary enclosures must 
also be kept in good repair. 
3.154(b) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The physical environment for multiple bird species including amazon parrots and macaws had either no or very limited 
enrichment through materials or activities. There was no additional cage complexity provided, nor objects to manipulate or 
any use of foraging or task-oriented feeding methods. The macaws were observed chewing on the wire panels of the 
enclosure. These behavioral signs may indicate that enriching the physical environment is necessary to provide the birds 
with means to express non-injurious species typical activities. The physical environment in primary enclosures must be 
enriched by materials or activities at an appropriate frequency to promote needs the psychological welfare of the birds. 
Correct by January 1, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
